answer_html: The first equation tells us k=1 but the other two equations then say that 1=-1 and 2=-1 which are both false and therefore there does not exist a unique k such that x=ky and thus x and y are not multiples of one another so they are not linearly dependent.
answer_latex:
The first equation tells us \emph{k}=1 but the other two equations then
say that 1=-1 and 2=-1 which are both false and therefore there does not
exist a unique \emph{k} such that \textbf{x}=\emph{k}\textbf{y} and thus
\textbf{x} and \textbf{y} are not multiples of one another so they are
\textbf{not} linearly dependent.
hints_html: Two vectors x and y are linearly dependent if one is a multiple of the other.
hints_latex:
Two vectors \textbf{x} and \textbf{y} are linearly dependent if one is a
multiple of the other.
hints_raw: Two vectors '''x''' and '''y''' are linearly dependent if one is a multiple of the other.
question: A 03
sols_html:
From the hint we see that two vectors x and y are linearly dependent if they are multiples of one another. This would mean that we can write,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}=k\mathbf{y}\end{aligned}\]

for some constant k. This is equivalent to

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} =k \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

or

\[\begin{aligned} 1&=k\\ -1&=k\\ -1&=2k\end{aligned}\]

The first equation tells us k=1 but the other two equations then say that 1=-1 and 2=-1 which are both false and therefore there does not exist a unique k such that x=ky and thus x and y are not multiples of one another so they are not linearly dependent.
sols_raw:
From the hint we see that two vectors '''x''' and '''y''' are linearly dependent if they are multiples of one another. This would mean that we can write,

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=k\mathbf{y}
</math>

for some constant ''k''.  This is equivalent to

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
=k
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

or

:<math>
\begin{align}
1&=k\\
-1&=k\\
-1&=2k
\end{align}
</math>

The first equation tells us ''k''=1 but the other two equations then say that 1=-1 and 2=-1 which are both false and therefore there does not exist a unique ''k'' such that '''x'''=''k'''''y''' and thus '''x''' and '''y''' are not multiples of one another so they are '''not''' linearly dependent.
statement_html:
For questions A1-A3 below, \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(\mathbf{y}\) are the given vectors below.

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x} = [1,-1,-1], \quad \mathbf{y} = [1,1,2],\end{aligned}\]

A3: Are \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(\mathbf{y}\) linearly independent? Justify briefly.
statement_latex:
For questions A1-A3 below, $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ are the given
vectors below.

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{x} = [1,-1,-1], \quad \mathbf{y} = [1,1,2],
\end{align*}

A3: Are $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ linearly independent? Justify
briefly.
statement_raw:
For questions <b>A1-A3</b> below, <math> \mathbf{x}</math> and <math> \mathbf{y}</math> are the given vectors below.

:<math>
\mathbf{x} = [1,-1,-1], \quad \mathbf{y} = [1,1,2],
</math>

<b>A3</b>: Are <math>\mathbf{x}</math> and <math>\mathbf{y}</math> linearly independent? Justify briefly.
